author: Cauchy
statement: The contour integral of a function around a closed curve is equal to 2πi times the sum of residues of the function at the poles enclosed by the curve.
breakdown: C is a positively oriented simple closed contour, f(z) is a function analytic on and inside C except at the poles a_1, ..., a_n, Res(f, a_k) is the residue of f at a_k.

author: Euclid
statement: In a right-angled triangle, the square of the hypotenuse is equal to the sum of the squares of the other two sides.
breakdown: a and b are the lengths of the legs of a right-angled triangle, and c is the length of the hypotenuse.

author: Pythagoras
statement: In a right-angled triangle, the square of the hypotenuse is equal to the sum of the squares of the other two sides.
breakdown: a and b are the lengths of the legs of a right-angled triangle, and c is the length of the hypotenuse.

author: Fermat
statement: There are no positive integers x, y, and z such that x^n + y^n = z^n for any integer value of n greater than 2.
breakdown: x, y, and z are positive integers, and n is an integer greater than 2.

author: Gauss
statement: Two integers a and b are congruent modulo n if their difference is an integer multiple of n.
breakdown: a and b are integers, and n is a positive integer.

author: Newton
statement: The force acting on an object is equal to the mass of the object times its acceleration.
breakdown: F is the force, m is the mass, and a is the acceleration.

author: Riemann
statement: The nontrivial zeros of the Riemann zeta function all have a real part of 1/2.
breakdown: ζ(s) is the Riemann zeta function, and s is a complex number.

author: Euler
statement: For any convex polyhedron, the number of vertices minus the number of edges plus the number of faces is equal to 2.
breakdown: V is the number of vertices, E is the number of edges, and F is the number of faces.

author: Gödel
statement: For any statement P(x), if P(x) implies Q(x) for all x, then Q(x) is true whenever P(x) is true.
breakdown: P(x) and Q(x) are logical statements involving x.

author: Cantor
statement: Two sets A and B have the same cardinality if there is a one-to-one correspondence between the elements of A and B.
breakdown: A and B are sets, and |A| and |B| denote their cardinalities.

author: Poincaré
statement: Every simply connected, closed 3-manifold is homeomorphic to the 3-sphere.
breakdown: S^3 is the 3-sphere, and a 3-manifold is a space that locally resembles Euclidean 3-dimensional space.

author: Galois
statement: The field extension of the rationals obtained by adjoining the square root of a non-square integer d is a quadratic field.
breakdown: Q(√d) denotes the field extension of the rationals with the square root of d.

author: Fourier
statement: A periodic function can be represented as a sum of sines and cosines or as a sum of complex exponentials.
breakdown: f(x) is a periodic function, and c_n are its Fourier coefficients.

author: Hamilton
statement: The quaternions are a number system that extends the complex numbers.
breakdown: i, j, and k are the fundamental quaternion units.

author: Abel
statement: The symmetric group on n elements is the group of all permutations of n elements.
breakdown: S_n is the symmetric group on n elements.

author: von Neumann
statement: The value of a zero-sum game is the maximum of the minimum payoffs.
breakdown: v(N) is the value of the game, x and y are strategies, and u(x, y) is the payoff function.

author: Ramanujan
statement: The sum of all natural numbers can be assigned a value of -1/12 through analytical continuation.
breakdown: The series 1 + 2 + 3 + ... diverges, but can be assigned a finite value using advanced techniques.

author: Wiener
statement: Wiener process, also known as Brownian motion, is a continuous-time stochastic process.
breakdown: W(t) represents the Wiener process at time t, and B(s) is a Brownian motion.

author: Klein
statement: The equation represents the 3-sphere in four-dimensional space.
breakdown: x, y, z, and w are coordinates in four-dimensional space.

author: Sophie Germain
statement: A Sophie Germain prime is a prime number p such that 2p + 1 is also prime.
breakdown: p is a prime number, and 2p + 1 is also a prime number.

author: Leibniz
statement: The definite integral of a function f(x) from a to b is equal to the difference of its antiderivative evaluated at b and a.
breakdown: f(x) is the function to be integrated, F(x) is the antiderivative of f(x), and a and b are the limits of integration.

author: Dedekind
statement: The field extension of the rationals obtained by adjoining the square root of a non-square integer d is a quadratic field.
breakdown: Q(√d) denotes the field extension of the rationals with the square root of d.

author: Cauchy
statement: The limit of a sequence a_n as n approaches infinity is equal to L.
breakdown: a_n is a sequence of numbers, and L is the limit that the sequence approaches.

author: Nash
statement: A Nash equilibrium is a situation in which no player can gain by unilaterally changing their strategy if the strategies of the others remain unchanged.
breakdown: In a Nash equilibrium, each player's strategy is optimal given the strategies of all other players.

author: Atiyah
statement: The index of an elliptic differential operator D is equal to the dimension of its kernel minus the dimension of its cokernel.
breakdown: Index(D) is the index of the operator D, Ker(D) is its kernel, and Coker(D) is its cokernel.

author: Mumford
statement: Proj(R) denotes the projective spectrum of a graded ring R, which is a fundamental object in algebraic geometry.
breakdown: R is a graded ring, and Proj(R) is the set of homogeneous prime ideals of R.

author: Grothendieck
statement: The i-th cohomology group of a sheaf \mathcal{F} on a topological space X represents derived functors of the global sections functor.
breakdown: H^i(X, \mathcal{F}) is the i-th cohomology group, X is a topological space, and \mathcal{F} is a sheaf.

author: Milnor
statement: The connected sum of two manifolds M and N is a new manifold formed by removing a ball from each and gluing along the boundary.
breakdown: M and N are manifolds, and M \# N is their connected sum.

author: Kolmogorov
latex-expression: P(A \cup B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A \cap B)
statement: The probability of the union of two events A and B is equal to the sum of the probabilities of A and B minus the probability of their intersection.
breakdown: P(A) and P(B) are the probabilities of events A and B, respectively, and P(A ∩ B) is the probability of their intersection.

author: Noether
statement: The i-th cohomology group of a group G with coefficients in a G-module M represents derived functors of the invariants functor.
breakdown: H^i(G, M) is the i-th cohomology group, G is a group, and M is a G-module.

author: Fermat
statement: There are no positive integers x, y, and z such that x^n + y^n = z^n for any integer value of n greater than 2.
breakdown: x, y, and z are positive integers, and n is an integer greater than 2.

author: Lagrange
statement: Every positive integer can be expressed as the sum of four squares.
breakdown: a is a positive integer, and b, c, d, and e are integers.

author: Bayes
statement: The probability of event A given event B is equal to the probability of event B given event A times the probability of event A divided by the probability of event B.
breakdown: P(A|B) is the conditional probability of A given B, P(B|A) is the conditional probability of B given A, P(A) is the probability of A, and P(B) is the probability of B.

author: Fibonacci
statement: Each number in the Fibonacci sequence is the sum of the two preceding ones, starting from 0 and 1.
breakdown: F_n is the nth Fibonacci number, F_{n-1} is the previous Fibonacci number, and F_{n-2} is the Fibonacci number before that.

author: Gauss
statement: Two integers a and b are congruent modulo n if their difference is an integer multiple of n.
breakdown: a and b are integers, and n is a positive integer.

author: Hilbert
statement: For any statement P(x), if P(x) implies Q(x) for all x, then Q(x) is true whenever P(x) is true.
breakdown: P(x) and Q(x) are logical statements involving x.

author: Erdős
statement: The Ramsey number R(m, n) is the minimum number of vertices required to ensure that a graph contains either a clique of size m or an independent set of size n.
breakdown: R(m, n) is the Ramsey number, and m and n are positive integers.

author: Dirac
statement: The time evolution of a quantum state is governed by the Schrödinger equation.
breakdown: ψ is the quantum state, H is the Hamiltonian operator, and t is time.

author: Wiles
statement: There are no positive integers x, y, and z such that x^n + y^n = z^n for any integer value of n greater than 2.
breakdown: x, y, and z are positive integers, and n is an integer greater than 2.

author: Turing
statement: There exist undecidable problems, meaning there are problems that no algorithm can solve for all inputs.
breakdown: A and B are sets of natural numbers, and A is not Turing reducible to B.
